none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. H. Dinwiddie, February 8, 1883
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from H. H. Dinwiddie, February 8, 1883
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 13 Louis L. McInnis Papers
Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas

en: A letter from H. H. Dinwiddie, faculty member at the Department of Chemistry and Physics at Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas, to Louis L. McInnis dated February 8, 1883. Dinwiddie reports on the declining health condition of a person referred to as "G." and provides updates on other ill students at the college suffering from measles. The letter reflects on mortality and human vulnerability during a time of medical crisis within the college community.

body.value:
[Header]

Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas,

DEPARTMENT OF
CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS.
H. H. DINWIDDIE.

College Station, Texas, Feb 8 1883

My dear McInnis -
I know you will be very
anxious about G. and hence I write hastily
to say that he is plainly no better. I saw
him an hour or so ago. He did not speak to
me. Every thing else goes on as usual. The boys
with measles are doing fairly. I suppose by
this time you have had at least one astounding
aspiration presented to you. In the presence of
great Death how puny seem these petty human
intrigues! It is a time to try our manhood. May
we all be equal to it!

Tell Col. James I have just seen his mother. They
are all well -

Yours as ever

[Signature]

H. H. Dinwiddie

**Transcription of a Handwritten Letter** Okay, here's what I've got. I need to transcribe this handwritten letter, following the instructions precisely. It starts with the header: *Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas,* followed by a sub-header on the left side: DEPARTMENT OF CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS. H. H. DINWIDDIE. On the right, it has the date: College Station, Texas, Feb 8 1883. "Feb 8" and "3" are handwritten. Next comes the body. The letter begins "My dear McInnis -" and I'll preserve all the line breaks. ```html

Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas,

DEPARTMENT OF
CHEMISTRY AND PHYSICS.
H. H. DINWIDDIE.

College Station, Texas, Feb 8 1883

My dear McInnis -
I know you will be very
anxious about G. and hence I write hastily
to say that he is plainly no better. I saw
him an hour or so ago. He did not speak to
me. Every thing else goes on as usual. The boys
with measles are doing fairly. I suppose by
this time you have had at least one astounding
aspiration presented to you. In the presence of
great Death how puny seem these petty human
intrigues! It is a time to try our manhood. May
we all be equal to it!

Tell Col. James I have just seen his mother. They
are all well -

Yours as ever
[Signature]
H. H. Dinwiddie

``` I checked the handwriting for “aspiration” and confirmed it is correct. Also checked "Every thing". Col. James is a "Col.". The "G." is capital. Finally, the signature is "H.H. Dinwiddie". That should be accurate!
